Name: 3-Phenoxybenzoic acid
Description: 3-phenoxybenzoic acid is a phenoxybenzoic acid in which the phenoxy group is meta to the carboxy group. It is a metabolite of pyrethroid insecticides. It has a role as a human xenobiotic metabolite and a marine xenobiotic metabolite.

plant_translocations.content: The uptake of 14C-labeled 3-phenoxybenzoic acid (I) was investigated in Myriophyllum elatinoides. The uptake of 14C-I, when dissolved in water and applied to the shoot/leaves, accounted for 15.85% of the applied radioactivity (AR) after 0.5 days, with minimal translocation of 14C to the roots over a period of 14 days. Slower uptake of radioactivity from 14C-I-treated sediment was observed in the roots, representing 6.37% of AR after 14 days, and 1.71% of AR was translocated to the shoot/leaves. Within the macrophyte, oxidation, reduction, and conjugation processes of compound I were observed.
plant_translocations.reference: Ando, D., Fujisawa, T., & Katagi, T. (2012). Uptake, translocation, and metabolism of 3-phenoxybenzoic acid in the submerged rooted macrophyte water milfoil (Myriophyllum elatinoides). Journal of Pesticide Science, 37(4), 342-346.

method.Plant Grown Condition: Greenhouse at 20±2°C under natural sunlight for at least 10 days, then transferred to a climate chamber at 20±2°C under white fluorescent lighting (120 µE·m−2 s−1, 16 hr per day) for 3 days
method.Chemical Preparation: 3-Phenoxybenzoic acid (I) uniformly labeled with 14C at the phenoxyphenyl ring (specific radioactivity, 4.37 GBq/mmol); other chemicals purchased from Sigma-Aldrich Co. or synthesized in the laboratory
method.Pesticide Application Details for the Pl: Application of 25–50 µL of 14C-I acetonitrile solution diluted with non-radiolabeled material I to the AAP medium in the shoot/leaves chamber (water treatment) or to the sediment in the roots chamber to establish an exposure concentration of 3.28 ppm (0.167 MBq)
method.Other Information: Plants were incubated in a glass vessel partitioned with a welded grass board into shoot/leaves and roots chambers, each filled with AAP medium or OECD sediment, respectively; each exposure was conducted in triplicate
